Award.AwardTitle: Mechanisms and Mitigation of Shrinkage and Carbonation in Alkali-Activated Concrete

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Alkali activated concretes (AACs) are promising green alternatives to conventional portland cement concrete, as they offer significant energy and CO2 savings that results from full (100%) replacement of portland cement with industrial waste products. However, these materials have not yet received broad industry acceptance, primarily due to their uncertain long-term durability performance against shrinkage/cracking, carbonation/corrosion, and alkali-aggregate reaction. The objectives of this work are to (1) advance the knowledge on the causes and mechanisms of shrinkage and carbonation of AACs at multiple length-scales, and (2) utilize this new knowledge to propose and evaluate effective mitigation strategies to promote production of high performance AAC materials. Three main alkali activated binders with vastly different compositions will be studied; a Ca-rich slag-based AAC, an Al-rich class F fly ash-based AAC, and a composite slag-fly ash binder, containing moderate levels of both Ca and Al. A novel research approach is proposed where the macro-scale shrinkage and carbonation performance is quantitatively linked to the material?s microstructure and phase-specific compositions and properties. This approach is based on integrating advanced characterization techniques (e.g., FIB, nano-indentation, NMR, SEM/EDS/ QXRD) with object oriented FEM simulations; and allows identifying the optimum material proportioning and processing practices that result in stable phase formation, and low risk of shrinkage and carbonation, without compromising strength and other performance requirements. In addition, chemical speciation modeling is used to design novel admixtures to reduce carbonation and to induce expansive reactions.

The research outcomes can be extremely beneficial towards improving the performance of alkali activated concretes, as well as portland cement and other alternative concrete materials. The research is well integrated with educational plans, including (a) outreach, recruitment, and retention of female and minority students in civil engineering education, research, and careers, and (b) providing a world-class research and teaching experience for graduate and undergraduate students. In addition, this work will contribute to engineering education literature by developing active learning and innovative student-centered instructional methods, and assessing the effectiveness of such methods in improving learning, engagement, and retention of students.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Concerns about the CO2 emission related to ordinary portland cement manufacturing have driven the development of alternative cementitious materials. Alkali-activated cement and concrete have been a promising option, as it can offer up to 80% reduction in CO2 emission and its production is primarily based on the use of industrial waste, including granulated ground blast-furnace slag and coal fly ash. However, the broad application of alkali-activated concrete has been hindered mainly due to its insufficient durability against shrinkage and micro-cracking. Alkali-activated concrete can undergo large shrinkage, which results in cracking and loss of durability and serviceability in restrained concrete elements. 

In this project, the mechanisms of high shrinkage in alkali-activated materials were extensively studied using a multi-scale approach and the several mitigation strategies were evaluated. It was found that the response of alkali-activated materials to drying-induced internal stress is highly compliant, in comparison to traditional portland cement materials, resulting in high shrinkage magnitude and characteristic visco-elastic/visco-plastic deformation. In other words, the high shrinkage of alkali-activated materials is attributed to the low stiffness of the solid skeleton. The cause of high visco-elastic/visco-plastic compliance of alkali-activated materials was further found to be attributed to the incorporation of alkali cation (Na+, K+) into the nanostructure of its main hydration products. The alkalis from alkaline solution at the beginning of mixing play an important role on the stiffness development of cementitious materials. This project illustrates that the composition and microstructure of cementitious materials have a considerable impact on its macroscopic performance. It also highlights the importance of limiting the amount of alkalis in concrete materials during material selection.

Several shrinkage mitigation strategies have been conducted in alkali-activated materials. High-temperature curing can significantly reduce the shrinkage of alkali-activated materials, likely by improving the stability and stiffness of solid skeleton. However, given the fact that the main component of shrinkage in alkali-activated materials is the long-term viscous deformation, mitigation of shrinkage through early-age expansion (including sulfate-enrichment and calcium-enrichment) does not seem to be very effective. In the atmospheric environment, the carbonation of alkali-activated slag can result in extensive micro-cracking and volumetric expansion. The mechanisms of volumetric expansion may be attributed to the crystallization stress of alkali-mixed calcium carbonates formed in restrained pore spaces. The volumetric expansion is also observed in alkali-rich portland cement system, while carbonation shrinkage is observed in the plain system. The volumetric change of cementitious materials with alkali-enrichment in the atmosphere is a result of competition between drying-induced shrinkage and crystallization-induced expansion. This competition can result in significant volumetric instability and disintegration of cementitious materials.

This study emphasizes that the search for novel activator (such as non-alkalis based activator) for waste aluminosilicate solids would be crucial to the further development of green concrete. The findings of this project suggest that the industrial waste materials, such as slag and fly ash, can be carefully designed and formulated to have similar and superior performance, in comparison to traditional portland cement. However, future work should focus on the design and selection of appropriate types of activators in alkali-activated materials.

Modified by: Aleksandra Radlinska
